hints.content:
Let's interpret the frequency table.

Distance | Number of Polar Bears
- | - 
$9\dfrac12\text{ m}$| ${\mid} = 1$ polar bear
$10\dfrac12\text{ m}$ | $\mid\mid\mid\mid=4$ polar bears
$11\text{ m}$ | ${\mid\mid\mid}=3$ polar bears
$12\dfrac{1}{2}\text{ m}$| $\mid\mid=2$ polar bears
Each tick mark on the number line represents an interval of ${\dfrac{1}{2}\text { m}}$.

There was $1$ polar bear that threw the snowball a distance of $\blueD{9\dfrac12\text { m}}$.  

So, we place $1$ dot over $\blueD{9\dfrac12}$ on the number line.   

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled distances (meters) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, and 13. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 1 dot above the unlabeled tick mark between 9 and 10. !

hints.content: Now, let's graph the other measurements on the frequency table.

The correctly graphed measurements are:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled distances (meters) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, and 13. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 1 dot above the unlabeled tick mark between 9 and 10, 4 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 10 and 11, 3 dots above 11, and 2 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 12 and 13. !

question.content:
A polar bear family had a snowball throwing contest.  They measured the length of their throws to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{2} \text{ m}$. 

Distance | Number of Polar Bears
- | - 
$9\dfrac12\text{ m}$| ${\mid}$
$10\dfrac12\text{ m}$ | $\mid\mid\mid\mid$
$11\text{ m}$ | ${\mid\mid\mid}$
$12\dfrac{1}{2}\text{ m}$| $\mid\mid$

**Graph the measurements from the frequency table on the following line plot.**   
*Click above the line plot to make dots for each of the measurements.*

[[☃ plotter 1]]
